content.description: Fun, overhanging problem in the Staircase area. On the bottom right corner of the boulder, start with hands matched on the sloper. Make some moves to left until you reach the arete. Using the slopey shelves of the arete, PULL hard and top out.
content.location: This route is located on the short arete next to Staircase

content.description: Climb the right arete, up and around the corner. Avoid using the boulder next to it.
content.location: Along the cliff side, search for the "Y" shaped tree. This route climbs the arete directly next to it.

content.description: Sit-start matched on a low jug. Make moves to the small crimps on the face, until you reach the juggy top out.
content.location: The start is located under the overhung section of the largest wall.

content.description: Start with your hands on the big flake and walk your feet up the staircase! Top out however you want. I was tired and couldn't get it.
Sit-start with hands matched in the pocket. Reach up for some jugs, and make some moves up the arete to top out.
content.location: Located on the ridge, just south of the Staircase area.

content.description: stand start. reach up, and mantle to the top!
Start with hands matched on the low shelf. Move up, and shoot your had into a nice pocket. Reset your feet, and make a few easy moves to the top.
content.location: On the arete to the right of Winding Staircase

content.description: Climbs the center of the face. Start with some crimps and small footholds. Work your way up to some bigger, friendlier holds and top out.
content.location: Biggest, and most obvious wall in the area. From the Staircase area, head south along the ridge about 150 feet.

content.description: Overhung start with a sloper and pinch. Follow the horizontal finger crack, and mantle up to the slabby finish.
content.location: Head to north side of the ridge to find this big boy. It has a rock wall near the bottom. This is where the problem starts.

content.description: Starts on the sloped shelf with awkward feet. Work up the arete, to the overhanging face. Set your feet, throw a heel, and top out.
content.location: On the arete next to Staircase.
Left-most part of the Staircase area.

content.description: Start on the big, juggy shelf on the right side of the wall. Traverse left, through the cruxy midsection using crimps and small footholds. Continue until you reach the start of Birdshot. Reach up to a few more crimps until you reach the top.
content.location: Traverses the largest wall in the area

content.description: Start as low as you can on the right overhang. Reach to the lip above, then mantle to the top.
content.location: next to the warm up arete

content.description: Starts on shelf, with feet in the small crack. Work your way up the face and top out.
content.location: Directly next to a large "Y" shaped tree

content.description: Start with hands matched in a crimpy pocket and good feet. Reach up to another crimp, and pull your way to the top.
content.location: Climbs the face of the biggest wall in the area

content.description: Start with good feet, and reach for jugs! The crux is probably topping out, due to the small footholds. This is where I took a fall and badly sprained my ankle (hence the name).
content.location: Right next to the start of High Hopes.

content.description: This route is an extended version of Winding Staircase. Start with hands matched on a sloper, and make some moves until you reach the arete. Use the rail to traverse left into the start of Staircase. Reset your feet, and make some easy moves to the top.
Climbs up and right past the 1944 inscription.
content.location: Locate the overhang with date scribed in the rock.

content.description:
10-20 ft sandstone / shale cliff on the east shore of Bruce Lake. Southwest facing. Nice sunset from the boulders, but don't forget you have to hike 2 miles back out! Potential for some nice overhanging problems, but mostly vertical / slight slab

 Note: This area is hard to access due to a 2 mile hike in, and is located in a protected state natural area. No camping is allowed. There is no mention of "no climbing", but please don't bolt or deface the rock in any way! Leave it better than you found it :)
